text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 6.771.1, Internal Revenue Service (IRS), Agency Grievance System (AGS).
This revised IRM incorporates Interim Guidance HCO-06-0320-0005 dated September 28, 2020.
) This revised IRM incorporates Interim Guidance HCO-
dated September

) This revised IRM changed references within IRM from LR/ER Strategic Policy Office to Associate Director, LR/ER Field Operations, Labor/ Employee Relations and Negotiations Division based on current organizational changes. (
) IRM
incorporates the Program Scope and Objectives subsection as required by the Internal Management Documents (IMD) System outlined in IRM
, Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) Process. (
) IRM

added deﬁnitions for Grievance Deciding Official, Formal Grievance, and Informal Grievance; removed deﬁnitions for Alternative Dispute Resolution and Deciding Official; and modiﬁed deﬁnitions for Days and Disciplinary Actions. (
) This revised IRM adjusts the timing within the reconsideration process.
This revised IRM adjusts the timing within the reconsideration process.
This IRM supersedes IRM 6.771.1 Internal Revenue Service, Agency Grievance System, dated October 23, 2012.
AUDIENCE
All Business Units.

Purpose: This IRM provides guidance on processing Non-Bargaining Unit (NBU) employee grievances.

) Audience: The policies, authorities, procedures, and instructions contained this IRM apply to all business units excluding Chief Counsel. This policy applies to NBU employees and BU employees with matters not covered by NA. (
) Policy Owner: The Human Capital Office (HCO). (
) Program Owner: Director, HCO Policy and Audits (P&A) and Labor/Employee Relations and Negotiations (LERN) divisions. (
) Primary Stakeholders: HCO P&A and LERN divisions. (
) Program Objectives: This IRM establishes the IRS Agency Grievance and procedures for employees to raise matters of concern or dissatisfaction management for consideration. (

) The IRS Human Capital Officer is the executive responsible for this IRM the Servicewide policy for agency grievances. (
) The HCO Office of HR Strategy’s Policy and Audits (P&A) division is respon- sible for developing, updating, publishing, and socializing this IRM content. (
) The HCO Office of HR Operations’ Labor/Employee Relations and Negotiations division collaborates with P&A on the IRM content and related communica-
The HCO Office of HR Operations’ Labor/Employee Relations and Negotiations division collaborates with P&A on the IRM content and related communica-
tions, ensures adherence to these IRM procedures, assists managers addressing agency grievances, and conducts periodic assessments of the fectiveness of the AGS. (

) Supervisors (managers) will: a. Resolve an employee’s concern(s) at the lowest level possible. b. Upon receipt of a grievance, forward a copy to the servicing Labor Relations Specialist (LRS) who will assist with processing the grievance. To ﬁnd the LRS point of contact (POC), refer to Labor Relations Contact Guide , HCO Staff Directory, LR Contact Guide. c. Determine if the grievance meets threshold issues (e.g., timely, grievable). Refer to IRM

d. Accept/Deny employee’s requested representative, if applicable. e. Determine if which manager is the appropriate Grievance Deciding Offi- cial (GDO) to resolve grievance. See IRM
) Employees will: a. Attempt to resolve their concern(s) with the immediate manager if they have authority to provide relief as an informal grievance prior to submit- ting IRS Form
, Agency Grievance and Authorization for Representative’s Access to Official Records. b. Comply with time limits in this IRM. c. Submit IRS Form

, Agency Grievance and Authorization for Repre- sentative’s Access to Official Records, with enough detail and supporting documentation (if applicable) to clearly describe the matter (issue). d. Specify the personal relief they are requesting. Management Review (
) This IRM provides policy guidance on the IRS Agency Grievance System. (

) The HCO P&A and LERN organizations gauge the effectiveness of this guidance by considering feedback from customers and stakeholders about subjects contained in this IRM. During the review and publishing of this IRM, sections are added, revised, or removed based on statutory and/or regulatory changes and based in part on this process. Controls (

) The P&A organization develops and deploys policies, materials, and programs to increase Servicewide awareness and understanding of the contents of IRM. Additionally, P&A collaborates with other HCO organizations and Service- wide stakeholders to support education and outreach activities as they relate the AGS. (
) To ensure this IRM policy and procedures remain current and compliant with regulations, the policy and program owners will annually review for changes. Terms/Deﬁnitions/Acronyms (

) Alternative Dispute Resolution (ADR): ADR is a phrase used to describe methods to resolve issues that are expeditious, less formal, and more cost effective than a court trial (e.g., negotiation, conciliation, mediation, etc.). is available for Equal Employment Opportunity (EEO) matters; however, it not available for agency grievances. (
) Control of IRS Management: a decision exclusively within the delegated authority of the IRS.

Control of IRS Management: a decision exclusively within the delegated
) Days: the grievant’s workdays per their tour of duty. Workdays excludes holidays and official office closure days. (
) Disciplinary Actions: for the purpose the AGS, includes admonishments, reprimands, and per Article
of the NA http://publish.no.irs.gov/ cat

, for BU employees, suspensions of
days or less. (

) Employee: an individual currently or formerly employed by the IRS for whom remedy (personal relief) is available including a bargaining unit employees for matters not covered by the NA NA http://publish.no.irs.gov/cat
cgi?request= CAT
&catnum=
) Executive Misconduct Unit (EMU) Employees: Employees covered by EMU include: Executives (ES; SL; AD); Executive Officers (IR-
); Senior Managers (IR-
); Frontline Managers (IR-
); and NBU GS-
This does not include those serving in an EMU position via a detail or a temporary promotion. (
) Factﬁnder: an individual assigned to a grievance case, upon request from Step
or Step

GDO. A factﬁnder gathers information and provides an inde- pendent, unbiased report documenting the relevant facts enabling the GDO make an informed decision. Factﬁnding may only be performed by persons involved in the grievance matter. Factﬁnders may not occupy a position subor- dinate to the manager(s) involved in the grievance; however, they may be in position subordinate to the GDO. Refer to IRM
I, Factﬁnding. (
) Factﬁnding: the process of investigating factual disputes about a grievance. (
) Factual Disputes: fact(s) in the grievance preventing the parties from resolving the concern(s). (
) Formal Grievance: begins when an employee completes and submits Form
, Agency Grievance and Authorization for Representative’s Access to Official Records to their First Level Manager. (

) Grievance: a request by an employee, or group of employees acting as indi- viduals, for personal relief in a matter of concern or dissatisfaction relating to their employment which is subject to the control of IRS management. This includes any allegation of coercion, reprisal (except in Equal Employment Op- portunity [EEO] cases) or retaliation, or any claimed violation, misinterpretation, or misapplication of any law, rule, or regulation affecting conditions of employ- ment. (
) Grievance Deciding Official: a manager designated to decide the outcome a formal grievance (submitted on Form
, Agency Grievance and Authoriza- tion for Representative’s Access to Official Records). The grievance process starts with the submission of Form

, Agency Grievance and Authorization for Representative’s Access to Official Records, to the frontline manager to determine the appropriate GDO. The GDO is the lowest level official who has authority to provide the requested relief and who was not involved in the grievance matter unless they are the Head of the Agency. In each step of the AGS, the GDO must be a higher grade than the GDO at the previous step. (

) Grievance Examiner: there is no provision for a grievance examiner in the AGS (except for disciplinary actions processed by the EMU). Refer inquiries EMU matters to Director, LERN Grievance System (AGS)
page (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Agency Grievance System (AGS) 6.771.1
Factﬁnding: the process of investigating factual disputes about a grievance.
) Grievance File/Case File: a ﬁle required and maintained by LERN, containing documents related to the grievance, including, but not limited to the informal grievance attempts to resolve, Form ,

, Agency Grievance and Authoriza- tion for Representative’s Access to Official Records, and supporting documentation, such as witness statements, factﬁnder/grievance examiner report(s), related correspondence, and all decisions (e.g., threshold, represen- tative, grievance). (
) Grievant: an employee or former IRS employee who ﬁles an informal/formal grievance. (

) Group Grievance: a group of employees submit a grievance about a subject affecting all members of the group. The group will identify a spokesperson present the grievance and participate in meetings on their behalf. The decision in a group grievance is binding on all. All participants must be identiﬁed by name and signature, indicating their voluntary participation at each step of grievance and their agreement to accept the ﬁnality of the administrative decision ultimately rendered. (
) Informal Grievance: begins when an employee attempts to resolve their concern(s) with management without ﬁling a formal grievance (Form
, Agency Grievance and Authorization for Representative’s Access to Official Records). (

) Payband: commonly known as performance-based pay or pay for perfor- mance. IRS managers (excluding executives) are on this pay system. Note: For Payband Employees with Performance concerns, refer to IRM
, Grievance Process-Performance Grievances for Payband Employees. (
) Personal Relief (remedy): a speciﬁc remedy/resolution directly beneﬁting grievant. (
) Representative: a person the grievant designates in writing (and allowed the GDO; refer to IRM
, Grievant’s Representative, to act on their behalf in the agency grievance process. (
) Senior Executive Services: A pay system for IRS executives. (
) Threshold Issue: a procedural determination of grievability, timeliness, and completeness of a grievance decided prior to considering the merits of the grievance. Refer to IRM
, Threshold Issues. (

Management may grant up to a total of four hours of administrative time to the grievant and their authorized representative to discuss, prepare, and present

the grievance. The AGS allows for a total of four hours of administrative regardless of the number of steps the grievance involves. a. The Grievant and authorized representative (if applicable) must request and receive approval for administrative time in advance. b. Use of government equipment (e.g., copiers, printers, and computers) requires advance approval. (
) Employees may choose a representative who is: a. Willing to serve, and b. Allowed by the GDO (refer to IRM
) Employees may designate a representative at any step of the AGS. (
) The grievant’s designation must be in writing and submitted to the GDO. (
) Only one individual may act as the representative. (
) The grievant may change the designation of a representative at any time. (

) The IRS will allow a grievant’s choice of representative unless such choice: a. Conﬂicts with the priority needs of the IRS - The IRS mission takes cedence. The requested representative may be disallowed if releasing the named employee would have a signiﬁcant negative impact on the IRS. This consideration uses the same criteria as annual leave approval. b. Creates a conﬂict of position - This occurs when the representative’s duties conﬂict with the functions of the representative. For example, requested representative participated in or has special knowledge the grievance by virtue of their assigned duties. c. Creates a conﬂict of interest - This can take many forms. For example, when a GDO’s supervisor is designated by the grievant to act as their representative. d. Or, Imposes unreasonable costs to the government - This can include any travel cost, or any expenses requested by the representative to their role. (

) The GDO will, within ten days of receiving the grievant’s designation of sentative, if applicable, provide the written disallowance notice to the employee and the disallowed representative. The disallowance notice includes the ant’s appeal rights and becomes part of the case ﬁle. (
) A grievant (not the disallowed representative) may appeal the decision to disallow the representative by: a. Submitting a written appeal (via email) within

days of receipt of a decision. b. Including the disallowance decision notice in the appeal. c. Sending the appeal to the LERN Associate Director, Field Operations Field Ops). To ﬁnd the name of the AD Field Ops, refer to HCO’s at http://hco.web.irs.gov/apps/staffdir/lrcontactguide.pdf . (
) Within
days of receiving the appeal regarding the representative decision, the AD Field Ops will make and communicate a ﬁnal decision on either

The Grievant and authorized representative (if applicable) must request and receive approval for administrative time in advance. Use of government equipment (e.g., copiers, printers, and computers) requires advance approval.
a. Submitting a written appeal (via email) within

days of receipt of a decision. b. Including the disallowance decision notice in the appeal. c. Sending the appeal to the LERN Associate Director, Field Operations (AD Field Ops). To ﬁnd the name of the AD Field Ops, refer to HCO’s website at http://hco.web.irs.gov/apps/staffdir/lrcontactguide.pdf .
Within 15 days of receiving the appeal regarding the representative decision, the AD Field Ops will make and communicate a ﬁnal decision on either
allowing or disallowing the representative. This action enables the grievance process to proceed and is not grievable. (

) The AGS is available to the following individuals: a. Current NBU employees. b. Current BU employees if the grievance issue is not covered under the NA (e.g., the ranking procedures used to ﬁll a supervisory position). c. Former IRS employees on a matter that arose during their IRS employ- ment with a plausible remedy (e.g., pay issue) after separation. (

) The AGS is not available to the following individuals: a. Applicants for employment b. BU employees if the matter is covered in the NA c. Chief Counsel employees d. Deceased employees unless the grievance involves a pay-related matter. (
) Except as listed below, the AGS applies to matters of concern or dissatisfac- tion relating to the employment of a covered employee that is subject to the control of IRS management. (

) Employees cannot ﬁle an EEO complaint and an agency grievance on the same issue. If an employee ﬁles a formal grievance through the AGS and ﬁles an EEO complaint for the same issue, whichever action was ﬁled ﬁrst prevails. Note: If an employee ﬁles an EEO complaint that is then rejected or denied, the employee may ﬁle an agency grievance within
workdays of receiving EEO decision provided the matter is grievable under the AGS (see exclu- sions in IRM

) The AGS excludes matters pertaining to: a. The content of established IRS regulations and policies. b. Any matter subject to review and adjudication by the Merit Systems tection Board (MSPB), the Office of Personnel Management (OPM), the Federal Labor Relations Authority, or the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission (EEOC). See IRM

, Appealable Decisions Excluded from the AGS. c. A matter administered by the Government Accountability Office or the Office of Workers’ Compensation Programs, Department of Labor. d. Any matter forwarded to the IRS Deputy Ethics Official for a review and decision. e. Non-selection for promotion from a group of properly ranked and certiﬁed candidates, or failure to receive a non-competitive promotion. f. The termination/separation of probationary employees for performance reasons. g. The termination or expiration of a time-limited excepted service appoint- ment or term appointment unless the employee does not have appeal rights under

k. The granting of, or failure to grant, or the amount of any type of discretion- ary award or recognition. l. The adoption of or failure to adopt an employee suggestion or invention. m. Any SES performance-based action or any decision regarding SES pay, awards, or performance evaluations. n. The expiration of an SES limited emergency or term appointment on the date speciﬁed as a condition of employment at the time of the appointment or promotion. o. Return of SES members to another pay system during their one-year pro- bationary period for less than fully successful executive performance, or failure to recertify, conditional recertiﬁcation or termination during probation for unacceptable performance. p. A receipt of an advance notice (proposal letter) for an action that has not been decided or taken place (e.g., a proposal for a suspension, adverse action, or an intent to deny a within grade increase). q. A receipt of a non-disciplinary action such as a cautionary, clearance, close without action or counseling memorandum or notice. r. A receipt of a mid-year performance appraisal. s. An action taken for violating a Service Agreement per IRM
, Ser- vicewide Travel Policies and Procedures, IRS Relocation Travel Guide. (

) If an employee wishes to formally grieve a work-related issue (other than a disciplinary action or an annual performance rating), they must present it on Form
, Agency Grievance and Authorization for Representative’s Access to Official Records, to their immediate supervisor within

days of the event the date the employee became aware of the matter being grieved. Employees should present a matter of concern about a continuing practice/condition as soon as possible. a. Grievances on disciplinary actions begin at Step
in the AGS with the Step
GDO. Refer to IRM
b. Grievances on annual performance ratings for non-payband employees begin at Step
in the AGS with the rating or reviewing official. Refer to IRM
c. Grievances on annual performance ratings for payband employees begin at Step
in the AGS with the Performance Review Board. Refer to IRM
) Within
days of the manager will review the Form
, Agency Grievance and Authorization for Representative’s Access to Official Records, and determine the appropriate GDO and forward the Form
and all supporting documents. (
) Within
days the GDO will review the Form

, Agency Grievance and Authorization for Representative’s Access to Official Records, and the support- ing documentation and issue a written threshold decision if any threshold issues apply. Refer to IRM

) Threshold issues include: • Timeliness Note: The employee has ﬁve days from receiving the threshold notice to resubmit a corrected/detailed grievance. • Completeness (varies based on the nature of the grievance) • Grievability - issue is excluded from AGS • Appropriate Scope - issue falls within the scope of the AGS procedures • Appropriateness of Representative - refer to IRM

) If the grievance does not meet all threshold issues, the GDO, in conjunction with the assigned LERN Associate, will provide a written threshold decision, including the steps to appeal, to the grievant within
days of receiving the grievance. Note: A meeting is not required. a. Employees may appeal a threshold decision via e-mail to the LERN Associate Director, Field Operations (AD Field Ops), within
days after
An allegation or complaint of discrimination appealable under 29 CFR 1614.
) If an employee wishes to formally grieve a work-related issue (other than a disciplinary action or an annual performance rating), they must present it on Form
, Agency Grievance and Authorization for Representative’s Access to Official Records, to their immediate supervisor within
days of the event or the date the employee became aware of the matter being grieved. Employees should present a matter of concern about a continuing practice/condition as soon as possible.
a. Grievances on disciplinary actions begin at Step

GDO. Refer to IRM

• Completeness (varies based on the nature of the grievance) • Grievability - issue is excluded from AGS • Appropriate Scope - issue falls within the scope of the AGS procedures • Appropriateness of Representative - refer to IRM

) If the grievance does not meet all threshold issues, the GDO, in conjunction with the assigned LERN Associate, will provide a written threshold decision, including the steps to appeal, to the grievant within
days of receiving the grievance.
Note: A meeting is not required.
Employees may appeal a threshold decision via e-mail to the LERN Associate Director, Field Operations (AD Field Ops), within
days after receipt of a threshold decision. To ﬁnd the name and e-mail address of the AD Field Ops, refer to HCO’s website http://hco.web.irs.gov/apps/ staffdir/lrcontactguide.pdf .
b. A response to the threshold appeal is issued within

days of receiving the appeal. The original is sent to the grievant and copies are sent to grievant’s supervisor, their representative if applicable, and the servicing LRS for inclusion in the grievance ﬁle. c. The Field Operations’ decision on the threshold issue(s) is ﬁnal, binding, and not subject to further review. (
) If the grievance meets all threshold issues, within

- Grievances Employees (

) Reconsideration of Rating - Each business unit or equivalent establishes written guidelines for the Performance Review Board (PRB) grievance proce- dures prior to any reconsideration. The procedures will identify the GDO designated to receive and consider appeals (Step
of the AGS). a. If a Payband employee wishes to grieve a performance rating, they submit their request on Form
, Agency Grievance and Authorization for Representative’s Access to Official Records, including all relevant formation to their designated PRB within

days from receiving the rating. The grievant will provide a copy of the grievance to their supervi- sor and the servicing LRS’ section chief. To determine which LR/ER office supports a business unit, refer to http://hco.web.irs.gov/apps/ staffdir/lrcontactguide.pdf . b. Within ﬁve days, the PRB will review Form

, Agency Grievance Authorization for Representative’s Access to Official Records, and sup- porting documentation and issue a written threshold decision if a thresh- old issue is not met for (e.g. Timeliness, Completeness and Grievability). Note: Completeness must contain a signed copy of the rating being grieved, the reason(s) grievant believes the rating to be incorrect, and the remedy requested. If the grievance is incomplete, it is returned. A corrected griev- ance may be resubmitted within ﬁve days of the PRB’s threshold notice. Note: Grievability - only payband performance ratings are grieved through this process. c. The PRB will consult with the servicing LRS at http://hco.web.irs.gov/ apps/staffdir/lrcontactguide.pdf before ﬁnalizing the decision. If the PRB determines the original or resubmitted grievance does not meet all threshold issues, the PBR will issue a written threshold decision to the grievant and send copies to the grievant’s supervisor and the servicing LRS. Note: Threshold decisions are ﬁnal, binding, and not subject to further review.

days (ﬁve days for PRB to determine threshold issues, ﬁve days for incom- plete grievances to be resubmitted, and ﬁve days to consider the merits of the request). If the threshold issues are met, the PRB may use all
days provide a written decision. (

appeals. (

) At any time prior to issuing the ﬁnal decision (at any Step), a GDO may cancel or reject a grievance: • At the employee’s request. • Due to the grievant’s termination/separation from the IRS unless a remedy for the former employee’s concern may be granted after termi- nation. • For failure to pursue the grievance in a timely and acceptable manner (e.g., the employee does not furnish or does not timely furnish informa- tion requested and necessary to address the concern). • For failure to specify the personal relief requested (remedy). • Because the matter(s) is not covered by the AGS or is not within man- agement’s control to resolve. • By an employee who is not covered by the AGS (e.g., a BU employee submits Form
when they should follow the NA Article
grievance procedures). • If the procedures in this IRM are not followed. (
) The written notice of cancellation or rejection will include: a. The reason(s) b. Citation(s) (e.g., an IRM section) c. Appeals rights with time limit (

) Send the appeal via email to the LERN Associate Director, Field Operations (AD Field Ops). To ﬁnd the name of the AD Field Ops, refer to HCO’s website at http://hco.web.irs.gov/apps/staffdir/lrcontactguide.pdf . (
) Within

days of receiving the appeal, the AD Field Ops will issue a written decision to the grievant and send copies to the grievant’s supervisor and the servicing LRS. • If the decision is upheld, the grievance is closed. The decision is ﬁnal, binding, and not subject to further review. • If the decision is in favor of the grievant, the grievance is returned to GDO to address the grievance.
